element.definition: TestScript is a resource that specifies a suite of tests against a FHIR server implementation to determine compliance against the FHIR specification.
An absolute URL that is used to identify this Test Script. This SHALL be a URL, SHOULD be globally unique, and SHOULD be an address at which this Test Script is (or will be) published.
element.short: Absolute URL used to reference this TestScript

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the TestScript. This is an arbitrary value managed by the TestScript author manually.
element.requirements: There may be multiple resource versions of the TestScript that have this same identifier. The resource version id will change for technical reasons, whereas the stated version number needs to be under the author's control.
element.short: Logical id for this version of the TestScript

element.comments: Not expected to be globally unique.
element.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the TestScript.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of a Value Set or Concept Map.

element.definition: The status of the TestScript.
element.requirements: Allows filtering of TestScripts that are appropriate for use vs. not.

element.definition: Identifier for the TestScript assigned for external purposes outside the context of FHIR.
This TestScript was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Allows filtering of TestScripts that are appropriate for use vs. not.
element.short: If for testing purposes, not real usage

element.comments: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the Test Script.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the Test Script.  May also allow for contact.
element.short: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)

element.comments: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.
element.definition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.comments: If there is no named individual, the telecom is for the organization as a whole.
element.definition: The name of an individual to contact regarding the Test Script.
element.short: Name of a individual to contact

element.definition: Contact details for individual (if a name was provided) or the publisher.
element.short: Contact details for individual or publisher

element.comments: Additional specific dates may be added as extensions.
element.definition: The date this version of the test tcript was published. The date must change when the business version changes, if it does, and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the test cases change.
element.short: Date for this version of the TestScript

element.comments: This field can be used for things such as why the TestScript was written, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc.  It is *not* a rendering of the TestScript as conveyed in TestScript.text. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the TestScript and its use.
element.short: Natural language description of the TestScript

binding.description: Indicates the countries, regions, disciplines and other aspects of use within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching of Test Scripts.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.
element.short: Content intends to support these contexts

element.comments: This element does not describe the usage of the Test Script (that's done in comments), rather it's for traceability of *why* the element is either needed or why the constraints exist as they do.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this data element.
element.definition: Explains why this Test Script is needed and why it's been constrained as it has.
element.short: Scope and Usage this Test Script is for

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the Test Script and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the details of the constraints and mappings.

constraint.human: TestScript metadata capability SHALL contain required or validated or both.
constraint.xpath: f:capability/f:required or f:capability/f:validated or (f:capability/f:required and f:capability/f:validated)

element.definition: The required capability must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.
element.name: metadata
element.short: Required capability that is assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested

element.definition: A link to the FHIR specification that this test is covering.
URL to a particular requirement or feature within the FHIR specification.
Short description of the link.

element.comments: When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.metadata or at TestScript.setup.metadata, and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then all the tests in the TestScript are skipped.  When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.test.metadata and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then only that test is skipped.  The "metadata.capabilities.required" and "metadata.capabilities.validated" elements only indicate whether the capabilities are the primary focus of the test script or not.  The do not impact the skipping logic.  Capabilities whose "metadata.capabilities.validated" flag is true are the primary focus of the test script.
element.definition: Capabilities that must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.
element.short: Capabilities  that are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested

element.definition: Whether or not the test execution will require the given capabilities of the server in order for this test script to execute.
Whether or not the test execution will validate the given capabilities of the server in order for this test script to execute.
Description of the capabilities that this test script is requiring the server to support.
element.short: The expected capabilities of the server

element.definition: Which server these requirements apply to.
element.short: Which server these requirements apply to

element.definition: Links to the FHIR specification that describes this interaction and the resources involved in more detail.

element.comments: The conformance statement of the server has to contain at a minimum the contents of the reference pointed to by this element.
element.definition: Minimum conformance required of server for test script to execute successfully.   If server does not meet at a minimum the reference conformance definition, then all tests in this script are skipped.
If the tests apply to more than one FHIR server (e.g. cross-server interoperability tests) then multiserver=true. Defaults to false if value is unspecified.
element.short: Whether or not the tests apply to more than one FHIR server

element.definition: Fixture in the test script - by reference (uri). All fixtures are required for the test script to execute.
element.short: Fixture in the test script - by reference (uri)

element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly create the fixture during setup. If true, the fixture is automatically created on each server being tested during setup, therefore no create operation is required for this fixture in the TestScript.setup section.
element.short: Whether or not to implicitly create the fixture during setup

element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly delete the fixture during teardown If true, the fixture is automatically deleted on each server being tested during teardown, therefore no delete operation is required for this fixture in the TestScript.teardown section.
element.short: Whether or not to implicitly delete the fixture during teardown

element.comments: See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types.
element.definition: Reference to the resource (containing the contents of the resource needed for operations).

element.comments: See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types.
element.definition: Reference to the profile to be used for validation.

element.comments: Variables would be set based either on XPath/JsonPath expressions against fixtures (static and response), or headerField evaluations against response headers. If variable evaluates to nodelist or anything other than a primitive value, then test engine would report error.  Variables would be used to perform clean replacements in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations. This limits the places that test engines would need to look for placeholders "${}".  Variables are scoped to the whole script. They are NOT evaluated at declaration. They are evaluated by test engine when used for substitutions in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations.  See example testscript-search.xml.

constraint.human: Variable cannot contain both headerField and path.
constraint.xpath: not(f:headerField and f:path)

element.definition: Variable is set based either on element value in response body or on header field value in the response headers.

element.comments: Placeholders would contain the variable name wrapped in ${} in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" elements.  These placeholders would need to be replaced by the variable value before the operation is executed.
element.definition: Descriptive name for this variable.

element.comments: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to.  If path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to.  It is an error to define both headerField and path.
element.definition: Will be used to grab the HTTP header field value from the headers that sourceId is pointing to.
element.short: HTTP header field name for source

element.comments: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to.  If path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to.  It is an error to define both headerField and path.
element.definition: XPath or JSONPath against the fixture body.  When variables are defined, either headerField must be specified or path, but not both.
element.short: XPath or JSONPath against the fixture body

element.comments: This can be a statically defined fixture (at the top of the testscript) or a dynamically set fixture created by responseId of the action.operation element.
element.definition: Fixture to evaluate the XPath/JSONPath expression or the headerField  against within this variable.
element.short: Fixture Id of source expression or headerField within this variable

element.definition: A series of required setup operations before tests are executed.
element.short: A series of required setup operations before tests are executed

constraint.human: Setup metadata capability SHALL contain required or validated or both.
constraint.xpath: f:capability/f:required or f:capability/f:validated or (f:capability/f:required and f:capability/f:validated)

element.definition: Capabilities that must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.
element.short: Capabilities  that are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested

element.comments: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.human: Setup action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.
constraint.xpath: (f:operation or f:assert) and not(f:operation and f:assert)

element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.short: A setup operation or assert to perform

constraint.human: Setup operation SHALL contain either sourceId or targetId or params or url.
constraint.xpath: f:sourceId or ((f:targetId or f:url or f:params) and (count(f:targetId) + count(f:url) + count(f:params) =1)) or (f:type/f:code/@value='conformance' or f:type/f:code/@value='search' or f:type/f:code/@value='transaction' or f:type/f:code/@value='history')

element.definition: The operation to perform.
element.name: operation

binding.description: The allowable operation types.

element.comments: See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/http.html for list of server interactions.
element.definition: Server interaction or operation type.
element.short: The setup operation type that will be executed

binding.description: Either a resource or a data type.

element.comments: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored. For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present. For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url. For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.
element.definition: The type of the resource.  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/resourcelist.html.

element.comments: This has no impact on the verification itself.
element.definition: The label would be used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.

element.comments: This has no impact on the verification itself.
element.definition: The description would be used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.

binding.description: The content or mime type.

element.comments: If this is specified, then test engine shall set the 'Accept' header to the corresponding value.    If 'xml' is specified, then 'Accept' header of 'application/xml+fhir' will be set.  If 'json' is specified, then 'application/json+fhir' will be used.    If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Accept' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.
element.definition: The content-type or mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Accept' header.

binding.description: The content or mime type.

element.comments: If this is specified, then test engine shall set the 'Content-Type' header to the corresponding value.    If 'xml' is specified, then 'Content-Type' header of 'application/xml+fhir' will be set.    If 'json' is specified, then 'application/json+fhir' will be used.    If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Content-Type' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.
element.definition: The content-type or mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Content-Type' header.
Which server to perform the operation on.
element.short: Which server to perform the operation on

element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly send the request url in encoded format. The default is true to match the standard RESTful client behavior. Set to false when communicating with a server that does not support encoded url paths.
element.short: Whether or not to send the request url in encoded format

element.comments: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored.  For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present.  For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url.  For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.   Test engines would append whatever is specified for "params" to the URL after the resource type without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP).  The "params" element does not correspond exactly to "search parameters".  Nor is it the "path".  It corresponds to the part of the URL that comes after the [type] (when "resource" element is specified); e.g. It corresponds to "/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}" in the following operation: GET [base]/[type]/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.
element.definition: Path plus parameters after [type].  Used to set parts of the request URL explicitly.

element.comments: This gives control to test-script writers to set headers explicitly based on test requirements.  It will allow for testing using:  - "If-Modified-Since" and "If-None-Match" headers.  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/http.html#2.1.0.5.1 - "If-Match" header.  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/http.html#2.1.0.11 - Conditional Create using "If-None-Exist".  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/http.html#2.1.0.13.1 - Invalid "Content-Type" header for negative testing. - etc.
element.definition: Header elements would be used to set HTTP headers.
element.short: Each operation can have one ore more header elements

element.comments: If header element is specified, then field is required.
element.definition: The HTTP header field e.g. "Accept".

element.comments: If header element is specified, then value is required.  No conversions will be done by Test Engine e.g. "xml" to "application/xml+fhir".  The values will be set in HTTP headers "as-is".  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.
element.definition: The value of the header e.g. "application/xml".

element.comments: If a responseId is supplied, and the server responds, then the resulting response (both headers and body) is mapped to the fixture ID (which may be entirely new and previously undeclared) designated by "responseId".  If responseId is not specified, it is the Test Engine's responsibility to store the response and use it as sourceId in subsequent assertions when assertion path and/or headerField is specified and sourceId is not specified.
element.definition: The fixture id (maybe new) to map to the response.
The id of the fixture used as the body of a PUT or POST request.
element.short: Fixture Id of body for PUT and POST requests

element.comments: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored.  For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present.  For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url.  For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.
element.definition: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id],  [type], and [vid] for GET requests.
element.short: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id],  [type], and [vid] for GET requests

element.comments: Used to set the request URL explicitly.  If "url" element is defined, then "targetId", "resource", and "params" elements will be ignored.  Test engines would use whatever is specified in "url" without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP).  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.
element.definition: Complete request URL.

element.comments: In order to evaluate an assertion, the request, response, and results of the most recently executed operation must always be maintained by the test engine.

constraint.human: Setup action assert shall contain both compareToSourceId and compareToSourcePath or neither.
constraint.xpath: (f:compareToSourceId and f:compareToSourcePath) or not(f:compareToSourceId or f:compareToSourcePath)

constraint.human: Only a single assertion SHALL be present within setup action assert element.
constraint.xpath: count(f:contentType) + count(f:headerField) + count(f:minimumId) + count(f:navigationLinks) + count(f:path) + count(f:resource) + count(f:responseCode) + count(f:response) + count(f:validateProfileId)  <=1

element.definition: Evaluates the results of previous operations to determine if the server under test behaves appropriately.
element.name: assert

element.comments: This has no impact on the verification itself.
element.definition: The label would be used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.

element.comments: This has no impact on the verification itself.
element.definition: The description would be used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.

binding.description: The type of direction to use for assertion.

element.definition: The direction to use for the assertion.

element.comments: The id of the fixture used to make comparisons to.
element.definition: Id of fixture used to compare the "sourceId/path" evaluations to.
element.short: Id of fixture used to compare the "sourceId/path" evaluations to

element.comments: The XPath or JSONPath expression to be evaluated against the expected fixture to compare to. Ignored if "assert.value" is used. The evaluation will be done before the assertion is evaluated.
element.definition: XPath or JSONPath expression against fixture used to compare the "sourceId/path" evaluations to.
element.short: XPath or JSONPath expression against fixture used to compare the "sourceId/path" evaluations to

binding.description: The content or mime type.

element.comments: If this is specified, then test engine shall confirm that the content-type of the last operation's headers is set to this value.  If "assert.sourceId" element is specified, then the evaluation will be done against the headers mapped to that sourceId (and not the last operation's headers).    If 'xml' is specified, then 'Content-Type' header of 'application/xml+fhir' will be confirmed. If 'json' is specified, then 'application/json+fhir' will be used. If you'd like to have more control over the string, then use 'assert.headerField' instead.
element.definition: The content-type or mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Content-Type' header.

element.comments: If "headerField" is specified then "value" must be specified.  If "sourceId" is not specified, then "headerField" will be evaluated against the last operation's response headers.  Test engines are to keep track of the last operation's response body and response headers.
element.definition: The HTTP header field name e.g. 'Location'.

element.comments: Asserts that the response contains all the element/content in another fixture pointed to by minimumId.  This can be a statically defined fixture or one that is dynamically set via responseId.
element.definition: The ID of a fixture.  Asserts that the response contains at a minimumId the fixture specified by minimumId.
element.short: Fixture Id of minimum content resource

element.comments: Asserts that the Bundle contains first, last, and next links.
element.definition: Whether or not the test execution performs validation on the bundle navigation links.

binding.description: The type of operator to use for assertion.

element.comments: Operators come handy especially for negative testing. If operator is not specified, then the "equals" operator is assumed; e.g. .
element.definition: The operator type.
element.short: equals | notEquals | in | notIn | greaterThan | lessThan | empty | notEmpty | contains | notContains

element.comments: If both "path" and "fixtureId" are specified, then the path will be evaluated against the responseBody mapped to the fixtureId.  If "path" is specified and "fixtureId" is not, then the path will be evaluated against the responseBody of the last operation.  Test engines are to store the response body and headers of the last operation at all times for subsequent assertions.
element.definition: The XPath or JSONPath expression to be evaluated against the fixture representing the response received from server.

binding.description: Either a resource or a data type.

element.comments: This will be expected resource type in response body e.g. in read, vread, search, etc.  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types; e.g. <assert > <resourceType value="Patient" </assert>.
element.definition: The type of the resource.  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/resourcelist.html.

binding.description: The type of response code to use for assertion.

element.comments: This is a shorter way of achieving similar verifications via "assert.responseCode".  If you need more control, then use "assert.responseCode"  e.g. <assert>  <contentType value="json" />  <response value="okay"/> </assert>.
element.definition: okay | created | noContent | notModified | bad | forbidden | notFound | methodNotAllowed | conflict | gone | preconditionFailed | unprocessable.
element.short: okay | created | noContent | notModified | bad | forbidden | notFound | methodNotAllowed | conflict | gone | preconditionFailed | unprocessable

element.comments: To be used with "operator" attribute value. Asserts that the response code equals this value if "operator" is not specified.   If the operator is "in" or "notIn" then the responseCode would be a comma-separated list of values e.g. "200,201". Otherwise, it's expected to be a numeric value.   If "fixture" is not specified, then the "responseBodyId" value of the last operation is assumed.
element.definition: The value of the HTTP response code to be tested.

element.comments: This can be a statically defined fixture (at the top of the testscript) or a dynamically set fixture created by responseId of the action.operation element.
element.definition: Fixture to evaluate the XPath/JSONPath expression or the headerField  against.
element.short: Fixture Id of source expression or headerField

element.comments: The ID of a Profile fixture. Asserts that the response is valid according to the Profile specified by validateProfileId.
element.definition: The ID of the Profile to validate against.
element.short: Profile Id of validation profile reference

element.comments: The string-representation of a number, string, or boolean that is expected.  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before comparing this value to the actual value.
element.definition: The value to compare to.

element.comments: If this element is specified and it is true, then assertion failures can be logged by test engine but should not stop the test script execution from proceeding.  There are likely cases where the spec is not clear on what should happen. If the spec says something is optional (maybe a response header for example), but a server doesnâ€™t do it, we could choose to issue a warning.
element.definition: Whether or not the test execution will produce a warning only on error for this assert.
element.short: Will this assert produce a warning only on error?

element.definition: A test in this script.

element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.
TestScript is a resource that specifies a suite of tests against a FHIR server implementation to determine compliance against the FHIR specification.

element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created

binding.description: A human language.

element.comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation

element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.

element.comments: When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.metadata or at TestScript.setup.metadata, and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then all the tests in the TestScript are skipped.  When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.test.metadata and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then only that test is skipped.  The "metadata.capabilities.required" and "metadata.capabilities.validated" elements only indicate whether the capabilities are the primary focus of the test script or not.  The do not impact the skipping logic.  Capabilities whose "metadata.capabilities.validated" flag is true are the primary focus of the test script.

element.comments: Variables would be set based either on XPath/JsonPath expressions against fixtures (static and response), or headerField evaluations against response headers. If variable evaluates to nodelist or anything other than a primitive value, then test engine would report error.  Variables would be used to perform clean replacements in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations. This limits the places that test engines would need to look for placeholders "${}".  Variables are scoped to the whole script. They are NOT evaluated at declaration. They are evaluated by test engine when used for substitutions in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations.  See example testscript-search.xml.

element.comments: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored. For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present. For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url. For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.

If 'xml' is specified, then 'Accept' header of 'application/xml+fhir' will be set.  If 'json' is specified, then 'application/json+fhir' will be used.    If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Accept' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.

If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Content-Type' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.

element.short: Whether or not to send the request url in encoded format

element.comments: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored.  For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present.  For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url.  For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.   Test engines would append whatever is specified for "params" to the URL after the resource type without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP).  The "params" element does not correspond exactly to "search parameters".  Nor is it the "path".  It corresponds to the part of the URL that comes after the [type] (when "resource" element is specified); e.g. It corresponds to "/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}" in the following operation: GET [base]/[type]/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.
element.definition: Path plus parameters after [type].  Used to set parts of the request URL explicitly.

See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/http.html#2.1.0.11 - Conditional Create using "If-None-Exist".  See http://hl7-fhir.github.io/http.html#2.1.0.13.1 - Invalid "Content-Type" header for negative testing. - etc.

element.comments: If a responseId is supplied, and the server responds, then the resulting response (both headers and body) is mapped to the fixture ID (which may be entirely new and previously undeclared) designated by "responseId".  If responseId is not specified, it is the Test Engine's responsibility to store the response and use it as sourceId in subsequent assertions when assertion path and/or headerField is specified and sourceId is not specified.
element.definition: The fixture id (maybe new) to map to the response.

element.comments: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored.  For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present.  For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url.  For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.
element.definition: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id],  [type], and [vid] for GET requests.

element.comments: Used to set the request URL explicitly.  If "url" element is defined, then "targetId", "resource", and "params" elements will be ignored. binding.description: The content or mime type.

element.comments: If this is specified, then test engine shall confirm that the content-type of the last operation's headers is set to this value.  If "assert.sourceId" element is specified, then the evaluation will be done against the headers mapped to that sourceId (and not the last operation's headers).    If 'xml' is specified, then 'Content-Type' header of 'application/xml+fhir' will be confirmed. If 'json' is specified, then 'application/json+fhir' will be used. If you'd like to have more control over the string, then use 'assert.headerField' instead.

element.comments: If "headerField" is specified then "value" must be specified.  If "sourceId" is not specified, then "headerField" will be evaluated against the last operation's response headers.  Test engines are to keep track of the last operation's response body and response headers.
element.definition: The HTTP header field name e.g. 'Location'.

element.comments: Asserts that the response contains all the element/content in another fixture pointed to by minimumId.  This can be a statically defined fixture or one that is dynamically set via responseId.

element.comments: Asserts that the Bundle contains first, last, and next links.

element.comments: If both "path" and "fixtureId" are specified, then the path will be evaluated against the responseBody mapped to the fixtureId. element.comments: If this element is specified and it is true, then assertion failures can be logged by test engine but should not stop the test script execution from proceeding.
